title: Ryan Farr's New York-Style Hot Dogs Recipe
full_text:
Ryan Farr's New York-Style Hot Dogs Recipe
Close
Jump to recipe
Prep
25 mins
Cook
70 mins
Active
2 hrs
Freezing and Chilling Time
16 hrs 20 mins
Total
17 hrs 55 mins
Serves
24 servings
Cook Mode
(Keep screen awake)
Ingredients
949
g
boneless lean beef
such as neck, plate, or shank, cut into 1-inch cubes
137
g
beef fat
, cut into 1-inch cubes
23
g
fine sea salt
10
g
paprika
5
g
granulated garlic
4
g
coarsely ground black pepper
3
g
onion powder
1
g
Instacure #1 or Prague powder #1
230
g
crushed
ice
20
feet
of
rinsed sheep casings
Directions
Place the meat and fat on a rimmed baking sheet, transfer to the freezer, and chill until crunchy on the exterior but not frozen solid.
Serious Eats / J. Kenji López-Alt
Serious Eats / J. Kenji López-Alt
In a small bowl, add salt, paprika, granulated garlic, black pepper, onion powder, and Instacure #1 and stir to combine.
Serious Eats / J. Kenji López-Alt
Nest a large mixing bowl in a bowl filled with ice. Grind the meat and fat through the 1/4-inch plate of the grinder into the bowl set in ice.
Serious Eats / J. Kenji López-Alt
Add spice mixture to the meat and stir with your hands until well incorporated; the mixture will look homogenous and will begin sticking to the bowl.
Serious Eats / J. Kenji López-Alt
Transfer meat to the bowl of a food processor, add half the crushed ice and process until all of the ice has dissolved, 1 to 2 minutes. Add the remaining crushed ice and continue processing until the mixture is completely smooth, 4 to 5 minutes more. Note: The temperature of your meat during this mixing step is critically important. Its temperature should never rise about 40°F (4°C); work efficiently during this step of the process.
Serious Eats / J. Kenji López-Alt
Serious Eats / J. Kenji López-Alt
Spoon 2 tablespoons of the meat mixture into a nonstick frying pan and spread into a thin patty. Cook the test patty over low heat until cooked through but not browned. Taste the sausage for seasoning and adjust as necessary.
Serious Eats / J. Kenji López-Alt
Press a sheet of parchment paper or plastic wrap directly on the surface of the meat to prevent oxidation, then cover the bowl tightly with plastic wrap and refrigerate overnight. Alternatively, you can vacuum seal the farce.
Stuff the sausage into the sheep casings and twist into links.
Serious Eats / J. Kenji López-Alt
Serious Eats / J. Kenji López-Alt
Smoke the links at 170°F (77°C), using
a smoker
or the oven set-up described above until the internal temperature of the sausage reaches 145°F (63°C), 45 to 60 minutes. Remove sausages from the smoker, let cool slightly, then transfer to the refrigerator and let stand, uncovered, overnight. The hot dogs are then fully cooked, and can be finished on a
grill
, steamed, or pan-fried.
Serious Eats / J. Kenji López-Alt
Special Equipment
Meat grinder
,
food processor
, vertical sausage stuffer,
smoker
Notes
To smoke in a gas oven, you can place the hot dogs on one side of a rack in a wide, deep baking dish, place smoldering wood chunks on the other, and cover the whole thing tightly with foil to trap the smoke before placing them in the oven.
